cover.subtitle: Communication Made Easy
cover.tagline: Connect with your baby before they can talk

introWhy.title: Why Baby Hands Talk?
introWhy.intro1: Here's something amazing: your baby understands far more than they can say. Between 6 and 8 months, babies develop a strong desire to communicateâ€”they want to tell you what they need, what they see, and how they feel. But here's the challenge: the complex motor skills needed for speech don't fully develop until around 18 months, and clear verbal communication often doesn't come until age 2 or 3.
introWhy.intro2: This creates a "communication gap"â€”a period where your baby has so much to say but no way to say it. That's where Baby Hands Talk comes in.
introWhy.highlightBox: Baby Hands Talk bridges this gap. Using simple hand gestures, your little one can tell you they're hungry, tired, want more, or even that they love youâ€”months before they can speak these words.

reducesFrustration.title: Reduces Frustration
reducesFrustration.description: When babies can express their needsâ€”whether it's pain, hunger, or wanting a specific toyâ€”tantrums and crying decrease dramatically. You'll spend less time guessing and more time connecting.

boostsBrainDevelopment.title: Boosts Brain Development
boostsBrainDevelopment.description: When your baby signs, they're activating multiple brain areas simultaneouslyâ€”visual, auditory, and motor. This creates stronger neural connections and enhances overall cognitive development.

deepensYourBond.title: Deepens Your Bond
deepensYourBond.description: Two-way communication creates a powerful emotional connection. When your baby asks to play ball and you understand, both of you feel seen, heard, and connected.

acceleratesSpeech.title: Accelerates Speech
acceleratesSpeech.description: Signing babies don't speak laterâ€”they often speak earlier and with larger vocabularies. The signs serve as a bridge to verbal language, not a replacement.

buildsConfidence.title: Builds Confidence
buildsConfidence.description: Being understood gives babies a sense of accomplishment and self-worth. They become active participants in family life rather than passive observers.

supportsEmotionalGrowth.title: Supports Emotional Growth
supportsEmotionalGrowth.description: Signs help babies identify and express emotions like happy, sad, or scared. This early emotional vocabulary is the foundation for healthy self-regulation.

introWhy.researchNote: ðŸ“š Research shows: Studies found that babies who signed were speaking like children 4 months ahead by age 2, and nearly a full year ahead by age 3. At age 8, these children scored an average of 12 points higher on IQ tests than their non-signing peers.

introTips.title: Tips for Success

faceToFace.name: Face to Face
faceToFace.description: The gold standard! Get down to their eye level when possible.

inFrontOfMirror.name: In Front of Mirror
inFrontOfMirror.description: Baby sees both you signing and themselvesâ€”great for learning!

onTheirBody.name: On Their Body
onTheirBody.description: For signs like EAT or BATH, gently sign on baby so they feel it too.

introTips.checklistTitle: âœ… How to Know Baby is Really Signing
introTips.checklistIntro: Not sure if that hand movement was intentional? Look for these three signs:

intentional.label: Intentional
intentional.description: Used to express a real need in the right context

independent.label: Independent
independent.description: Not copying youâ€”they initiate it on their own

consistent.label: Consistent
consistent.description: They use it repeatedly, not just a one-time thing

tip1.title: Sign with the Action
tip1.description: Always sign during, just before, or right after the action. "Time for BATH" as you turn on the water helps baby connect sign, word, and meaning.

tip2.title: Be Consistent
tip2.description: Use the same sign every time. The more you sign throughout the day, the faster baby will sign back. Try placing reminder notes in key areas!

tip3.title: Repeat Naturally
tip3.description: "We're going to BATH. Daddy is giving you a BATH. All done with BATH!" Repetition during activities reinforces learningâ€”just don't overdo it.

tip4.title: Make Eye Contact
tip4.description: Unlike speech, signing requires visual attention. Try to be in baby's line of sight. But if they're not looking, sign anywayâ€”you're building the habit!

tip5.title: Keep It Fun
tip5.description: Babies learn through play, not memorization! Use signs during songs, games, and storytime. Their interest grows much faster when it's enjoyable.

tip6.title: Celebrate Every Attempt
tip6.description: Baby's sign won't look perfectâ€”and that's okay! Respond enthusiastically to any approximation. They'll refine it over time by watching you model it correctly.

tip7.title: Don't Stop When They Talk
tip7.description: Keep signing even after first words appear! Early speech is often unclear. Signs remain a valuable backup that prevents frustration. Let them phase out signs naturally.

tip8.title: Get Everyone Involved
tip8.description: Teach signs to partners, grandparents, caregivers, and siblings. The more people who sign with baby, the faster they'll learn and the more connected they'll feel.

introTips.encouragement: Remember: Every baby learns at their own pace. Some sign back in weeks, others take months. What matters is the connection you're building. You've got this! ðŸŒŸ

introWhen.title: When to Start & What to Expect
introWhen.intro: Even in the womb, your baby begins recognizing your voice and the patterns of your language. From birth, they can distinguish your native language from others! Understanding your baby's developmental journey helps you know when and how to introduce signs.

0to6.title: The Watching Phase
0to6.description: During this stage, crying is your baby's main communication tool. They're absorbing everythingâ€”your voice, your expressions, your gestures. You can start signing now; your baby is watching and learning even if they can't respond yet.

6to8.title: Communicative Intent Emerges
6to8.description: A breakthrough moment! Your baby develops a strong urge to communicate. You'll notice them pointing, reaching, and making sounds with purpose. This is the ideal time to introduce signs consistently.

8to12.title: First Signs Appear
8to12.description: Most babies produce their first intentional sign during this window. It might look a little different from yoursâ€”that's completely normal! The motor skills for precise hand movements are still developing. Celebrate every attempt!

12to18.title: The Sign Explosion
12to18.description: Once your baby masters a few signs, learning accelerates rapidly. Many babies learn 10-20+ signs during this exciting period. They'll start combining signs and using them spontaneously throughout the day.

18to24.title: Bridge to Speech
18to24.description: As verbal skills develop, your child will naturally start replacing signs with words. Keep signing! Even when they say a word, they may not pronounce it clearly yet. Signs remain a helpful backup that prevents frustration.

introWhen.brainBoxTitle: ðŸ§  What's Happening in Your Baby's Brain
introWhen.brainBoxContent1: When you speak a word AND show a sign, your baby's brain lights up in multiple areas: the auditory cortex processes the sound, the visual cortex processes what they see, and when they sign back, the motor cortex gets involved too.
introWhen.brainBoxContent2: This multi-sensory experience creates stronger, more interconnected neural pathways. That's why signing babies often remember words more easilyâ€”they've stored them in multiple places in their brain!
introWhen.importantMessage: It's never too early or too late to start!
introWhen.importantHighlight: Whether you begin at 4 months or 14 months, what matters most is consistency, patience, and making it fun.
